title: What are some academically accepted criticisms to claims that Ramayana and Mahabharatha are historical events? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is what historian Nandita Krishnan jas to say about Ramayana “The Ramayana is geographically very correct. Every site on Rama's route is still identifiable and has continuing traditions or temples to commemorate Rama's visit. Around 1000 BC or earlier, no writer had the means to travel around the country inventing a story, fitting it into local folklore and building temples for greater credibility.” This is what historian Pushkar Bhatnagar says “geographical evidence for the epics is abundant. There still exist many places like Rameshwaram, Kishkindha, Kurukshetra, Hastinapura, etc. where the visits of Rama and Krishna are a basic part of local folklore.” Lack of archaeological evidence is no excuse for denying the existence of history, sums up Bhatnagar. "If the buildings of that time over 7000 years ago do not exist today, can we just infer that civilizations and personalities of that time also did not exist?" Taken from Stephen Knapp's website
For Ramayana :- Ram setu which is also called as Adam bridge. For Mahabharata :- Indus valley was destroyed and radiations are still there until today.
